title: The First Plague
shortSummary: Exodus chapter 7 introduces the initial confrontation between Moses, Aaron, and Pharaoh, as God begins to demonstrate His power through miraculous signs and judgments. This chapter sets the stage for the plagues on Egypt, revealing God's sovereignty and His plan to deliver Israel from bondage.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God’s chosen deliverer of Israel who confronts Pharaoh and performs signs by God's command.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ brother and spokesman who performs miracles before Pharaoh as directed by God.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The ruler of Egypt who resists God’s command to release the Israelites, his heart hardened by God.

keyCharacters.name: Egyptian Magicians
keyCharacters.description: Pharaoh’s wise men and sorcerers who replicate some of Aaron’s signs but are ultimately overcome.

definitions.definition: A biblical phrase meaning God sovereignly strengthens Pharaoh’s stubbornness to fulfill His purposes.
A staff used by Moses and Aaron as a symbol of God’s authority and power in performing miracles.
A snake; Aaron’s rod turning into a serpent demonstrates God’s power over Egyptian magic.
A divine judgment or calamity sent by God to compel Pharaoh to release the Israelites.

outline.heading: God Commissions Moses and Aaron
outline.description: God appoints Moses as a god to Pharaoh and Aaron as his prophet, promising to harden Pharaoh’s heart to display His power through signs and judgments.

outline.heading: Moses and Aaron Before Pharaoh: The Serpent Sign
outline.description: Moses and Aaron obey God’s command and perform the miracle of Aaron’s rod turning into a serpent, which is countered by Egyptian magicians but ultimately prevails.

outline.heading: God Declares Pharaoh’s Hardened Heart
outline.description: God reveals that Pharaoh’s heart is hardened and he refuses to release Israel, setting the stage for the coming judgments.

outline.heading: The First Plague: Water Turned to Blood
outline.description: God commands Moses and Aaron to strike the Nile, turning its waters to blood, killing fish and making the water undrinkable, yet Pharaoh’s heart remains unyielding.

application: Trust God’s sovereign plan even when circumstances seem difficult or opposition is strong.
Obey God’s commands faithfully, knowing He equips and empowers His servants to accomplish His will.
Recognize that God’s judgments serve to reveal His holiness and compel repentance.
Pray for God to soften hardened hearts, including our own, to respond rightly to His word.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Moses, See, I have made thee a god to Pharaoh: and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes Moses’ divinely appointed authority and Aaron’s role as spokesman in confronting Pharaoh.

keyVerses.text: And I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and multiply my signs and my wonders in the land of Egypt.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals God’s sovereign control over Pharaoh’s heart to fulfill His redemptive purposes through miraculous signs.

keyVerses.text: For they cast down every man his rod, and they became serpents: but Aaron's rod swallowed up their rods.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates God’s power surpassing the Egyptian magicians, affirming His supremacy over false gods and magic.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD, In this thou shalt know that I am the LORD: behold, I will smite with the rod that is in mine hand upon the waters which are in the river, and they shall be turned to blood.
keyVerses.significance: God declares the purpose of the first plague: to reveal His identity and authority as the one true God.
